name: Johns Hopkins Hyperbaric Medicine Program
description: Hospital-based hyperbaric oxygen therapy program at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center
notes: Hospital-based program, typically requires physician referral. Not FDA-approved for autism.

name: University of Maryland Hyperbaric Medicine
description: Academic medical center hyperbaric oxygen therapy program
notes: Hospital-based program at UMMC. Primarily treats wound healing, decompression sickness.

name: National Integrated Health Associates (NIHA)
description: Integrative medicine center offering hyperbaric oxygen therapy and other alternative treatments
notes: Private integrative medicine clinic. Near Maryland border. Offers HBOT for various conditions.

name: Chesapeake Hyperbarics
notes: Private HBOT center near Maryland. Offers mild hyperbaric therapy.

name: Shady Grove Fertility - Regenerative Medicine
notes: Regenerative medicine research. Stem cell therapy for autism is NOT FDA-approved.

name: Global Stem Cells Group - Maryland Affiliate
description: Stem cell therapy and regenerative medicine referral network
notes: CAUTION: Stem cell therapy for autism is NOT FDA-approved. Very limited evidence.

name: R3 Stem Cell Maryland
description: Regenerative medicine and stem cell therapy provider network
notes: CAUTION: Stem cell therapy for autism is NOT FDA-approved. Limited research. Very expensive.

name: Integrated Hyperbaric Center
description: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy center with focus on neurological conditions
notes: Offers mild HBOT (mHBOT). Some research suggests potential benefits for autism but not FDA-approved.

name: Documenting Hope / Epidemic Answers
description: Non-profit organization researching biomedical interventions for developmental disorders
notes: Research organization, not a treatment provider. Resources on biomedical approaches.

name: Kennedy Krieger Institute - Research Programs
description: Leading autism research institution with clinical trials for investigational treatments
notes: Check for clinical trials. Leading ASD research center.

name: Sulforaphane (Broccoli Sprout Extract)
description: Nrf2 activator found in broccoli sprouts. Multiple RCTs show improvements in social behavior and communication in ASD.
notes: Brands: Avmacol, BroccoMax, Prostaphane. 2014 PNAS study showed significant improvements. Generally well-tolerated. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: Omega-3 Fatty Acids (Fish Oil / DHA+EPA)
description: Essential fatty acids with anti-inflammatory properties. Some studies suggest benefits for behavior and attention in ASD.
notes: Mixed evidence. Generally safe at recommended doses. Look for high EPA+DHA content. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: Vitamin D3
description: Multiple studies link vitamin D deficiency to ASD. Some RCTs show behavioral improvements with supplementation.
notes: Test levels before supplementing (25-OH vitamin D test). Optimal range debated. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: Probiotics (Gut-Brain Axis)
description: Beneficial bacteria to support gut health. Research suggests gut microbiome differences in ASD.
notes: Strains studied: L. reuteri, B. infantis, VSL#3. May help GI symptoms. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: Methyl B12 (Methylcobalamin)
description: Active form of vitamin B12. Some studies suggest improvements in methylation and behavior in ASD.
notes: Often given as subcutaneous injection by integrative doctors. Oral/sublingual also available. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: Folinic Acid (Leucovorin)
description: Active form of folate. RCT showed improvements in verbal communication in children with ASD and folate receptor autoantibodies.
notes: 2018 RCT (Frye et al.) showed significant improvements. Test for FRAA antibodies. High-dose requires prescription. NOT FDA-approved for autism.

name: N-Acetyl Cysteine (NAC)
description: Antioxidant and glutathione precursor. Some studies show reduction in irritability in ASD.
notes: 2012 study showed reduced irritability. Generally well-tolerated. NOT FDA-approved for autism.
